bug.short_desc: New environment fields that indicate whether the browser displays a clear-searchfield-button

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1211 SearchField
I would like to request two new environment settings which could be requested by qx.core.Environment.get("searchfield.hasclearbutton") and qx.core.Environment.get("textfield.hasclearbutton"): - The first environment setting should return whether the browser automatically displays a button that clears the input of a textfield - The second environment setting should return whether the browser automatically display a button that clears the input of a field of type "search"
We have developed our own button that clears the input of a search field - see attached screenshot. Now we have run into the problem that IE 10 also display such a button - which leads to two duplicate buttons. To avoid these duplicate buttons, we need the information whether the browser automatically displays such a button.

The input type "search" is a HTML5 feature currently supported by Chrome and Safari. To me this is clearly a feature and we should really think carefully if we want to prevent it. I would go just the other way around: use the feature if available otherwise polyfill it to enhance the user experience for all users. A good solution might be to offer a "search field" widget based on the current textfield widget which implements this polyfill for all browsers not capable showing an own "clear" icon.
IE10 is even more using this feature: it is used for all input elements. Plus a special handling for password fields. I expect that other browsers will soon follow and offer similar features. We should embrace these features instead of preventing them.
Anyway, if you are willing to omit these features you can simply add some lines of CSS to your HTML page.
--snip-- // prevents the "clear" icon on all input fields ::-ms-clear { display: none; } --snip-
And to hide the "reveal password" feature:
--snip-- ::-ms-reveal { display: none; } --snip--
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10842665/internet-explorer-10-windows-8-remove-text-input-and-password-action-icons for details.
My opinion is to leave this decision up to the application developer. He has to decide if he really likes to omit the HTML5 features of the browsers.
